content.webTitle: Grandmothers by Salley Vickers review – a gran for all seasons

fields.headline: Grandmothers by Salley Vickers review – a gran for all seasons
fields.bodyText: Near the beginning of Salley Vickers’s new novel, one of her characters says: “All ways of life have a cost.” For the trio of elderly main characters in Grandmothers, the cost appears to be the same: a sense that their value as grandmothers is underappreciated. Nan is grandmother to Billy, the only child of her son, Alec, and his ex-wife, Virginia. Nan’s husband, she discovered late in her marriage, was gay and forthright Nan now occupies her time planning for her funeral (which shows no signs of being imminent) and fulfilling her secret career as a successful poet. Blanche became estranged from her son and his family after she drove her grandchildren home drunk. Unable to acknowledge her responsibility for the family rift, she is bitter and angry and takes to shoplifting meaningless items from local stores. Minna, meanwhile, is a surrogate rather than biological grandmother. A neighbour’s child, Rose, spends much of her free time in the shepherd’s hut where Minna lives alone, following a disastrous affair with a married man decades earlier, which has left her heartbroken. What unites the three characters, who are unknown to each other at the beginning of the novel but become acquainted through a series of improbable encounters, is their belief that their grandchildren are ill-served by their parents and that they, as grandmothers, are far better equipped to understand and provide what their grandchildren need. Minna is critical of Rose’s mother, who “sporadically instituted a clearing out of what she considered an overpopulation of toys”, which Minna encourages Rose to bring to her home instead. Nan is resentful and censorious of her son, Alec, whom she feels is neglectful of Billy. Overbearing Blanche rails against “terrible, terrible Tina, for surely it was Tina, her daughter-in-law, who was behind all this” while demonstrating no remorse for her drink-driving. One assumes Vickers wants us to sympathise with her grandmothers, but their behaviour fails to elicit sympathy and she offers insufficient distinction between their predicaments for the reader to engage with. While Minna and Nan have tragic backstories, these neither explain nor excuse their sense of entitlement. In Vickers’s world, grandparents take precedence over parents, and grandmothers fill the void of their own maternal failings with an excessive involvement in their grandchildren’s lives. No parent in the novel is capable of a healthy relationship with their child, making for a rather bleak – and one-note – portrayal of extended family life. As with her previous novels, Vickers has a keen ear for dialogue and there are moments of wry humour. But while some important issues are explored here – loneliness, regret, intergenerational discord – the novel lacks the emotional breadth and narrative texture of a nuanced, engaging read. • Grandmothers by Salley Vickers is published by Viking (£16.99). To order a copy go to guardianbookshop.com. Free UK p&p over £15
